questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
This evaluates practical implementation of Vault's SSH secret engine in multi-tenant environments, focusing on security isolation, operational continuity, and proper handling of cryptographic rotations.

## Key Concepts
- Namespace-based tenant isolation in Vault Enterprise
- SSH certificate lifecycle management with ephemeral credentials
- Host key rotation strategies preserving session continuity
- Lease-based revocation and immediate access termination
- Cross-tenant isolation validation techniques
- Rolling deployment patterns for zero-downtime updates

## Code Example
```bash
# Create per-tenant SSH role
vault write ssh/roles/tenant1-jump \
  ttl=24h \
  max_ttl=24h \
  allowed_users="jumpuser" \
  allow_user_certificates=true \
  key_type="ca" \
  default_critical_options=["no-port-forwarding"] \
  default_extensions=["permit-X11-forwarding"]

# Sign SSH certificate for tenant user
vault write -field=signed_key ssh/sign/tenant1-jump \
  public_key=@/home/jumpuser/.ssh/id_rsa.pub \
  valid_principals=jumpuser \
  ttl=8h

# Revoke all tenant leases immediately
vault lease revoke -prefix ssh/creds/tenant1-jump

# Clean up tenant configuration
vault delete ssh/roles/tenant1-jump

# Host key rotation (conceptual)
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -f /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key -N ""
vault write ssh/config/ca host_key=@/etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key.pub
```
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  A(Tenant requests SSH) --> B(Vault issues ephemeral cert)
  B --> C(Client connects to jump host)
  C --> D(Host-key rotation every 24h)
  D --> E(Active sessions finish within TTL)
  E --> F(Tenant disabled triggers lease revocation)
  F --> G(Audit logs confirm isolation)
